isis.stitle: HEAT VENTILATION AIR CONDITIONING (HVAC) SYSTEM - ProStar - REMOVE AND INSTALL - HEATER HOUSING

note.para: Removing and installing the heater housing requires detaching and raising the Instrument Panel (IP), and removing the evaporator housing from the cowl. Replacement of the heater housing is necessary only if either the mode door mechanism or the housing itself is damaged. In either case the entire heater housing is replaced as an assembly.

svcprocinfo.para: The Instrument Panel (IP) must be detached and raised prior to removing the heater housing. Accessing the IP mounting hardware may require the removal of trim panels not described in this manual. The procedures provided here cover a basic installation. Refer to the appropriate CAB section in Group 16 of the Master Service Manual for additional procedures.

step1.para: Inside cab, remove A-pillar trim from driver's side.
Remove assist handle and A-pillar trim from passenger's side.
Remove or disconnect trim panels from under IP to allow access to IP mounting hardware removed in the following steps.

Remove only the IP mounting hardware required to allow IP to be raised about one inch. More complete procedures for removing the IP can be found in the appropriate CAB section in Group 16 of the Master Service Manual. Typically, the following mounting hardware must be removed:

step2.para: Remove five bolts (1, Figure 40) securing top of IP to dash panel (located near windshield).
Remove two bolts (2) securing steering column module to IP.
Remove two bolts (3) securing each side of IP to dash panel.

step1.para:
To gain access to mounting nuts (10, Figure 41) for the heater housing (1), the evaporator housing (11) must be removed from the cowl. Refer to AIR CONDITIONER (EVAPORATOR) HOUSING, REMOVE AND INSTALL
.

Remove heater core (5) from heater housing, refer to HEATER CORE, REMOVE AND INSTALL
.
Disconnect HVAC wiring harness (4) from instrument panel wiring harness.

note.para: It may be possible to remove the heater housing without disconnecting the passenger side floor duct (6); however, the following steps are provided as an alternative.
The driver side duct is connected to the heater housing with a snap mount (slip-lock). This duct is also mounted to the dash panel with one mounting screw.

There are two gaskets attached to the exterior of the heater housing. There is one gasket (12) where the housing mounts to the dash panel; and another gasket (2) where the IP rests on top of the housing. If the gaskets are damaged when moving the housing or the IP, they must be replaced.
In the following step, it will be necessary to raise the IP slightly while removing the heater housing. This may require a second or third person.

step1.para: Lift the IP and support it so that it provides the greatest amount of clearance for removing heater housing.
Disconnect passenger side floor duct (Items 2, 3, and 5, Figure 42) from heater housing.

step2.para: Bottom section of duct is mounted to side of housing with one screw (4). After removing screw, bottom section may be removed to provide better access to top section.
Top section of duct is connected to housing with a snap mount (slip-lock), and is disconnected by pulling duct away from housing.

step1.para: Remove mounting screw (8, Figure 41) from driver side floor duct (7) and move duct left to disconnect it from housing.
On engine side of dash panel, remove four nuts (10) from heater housing mounting studs.
Pull heater housing to rear (to allow its mounting studs to clear dash panel). Heater housing (1) should now be clear to slide out from under IP.
If mode door actuator (3) is being transferred to a replacement heater housing, remove two screws securing actuator to housing (1), and pull actuator straight off of mode door shaft.

note.para: It may be possible to install the heater housing with the passenger side floor duct already installed; however, the following procedure is provided as an alternative installation method.

step1.para: Carefully slip mode door actuator (3, Figure 41) from removed housing, onto end of mode door shaft so that mounting holes are properly aligned, if possible. If actuator drive collar must be moved to allow alignment:

step2.para: Place actuator into its approximate position.

To rotate drive collar, connect a 9 Volt battery across the active pins of the actuator connector (check mating connector if necessary). (Reverse connection to rotate drive collar in opposite direction.)
Allow drive collar to rotate until it is aligned with door shaft, and actuator mounting screws can be inserted. Then, disconnect battery.

step1.para: Secure actuator to heater housing using two screws.

note.para: In the following step, the IP must be raised slightly while installing the heater housing. This may require a second or third person. To insure proper alignment and compression of the heater housing top gasket, the IP must remain raised until the heater housing is securely mounted.
While performing the following steps be careful not to damage the gaskets when moving the heater housing or the IP.

step1.para: Lift and brace IP so that it provides adequate clearance for installing heater housing.
With IP raised, carefully position heater housing (1, Figure 41) under passenger side instrument panel, so that its mounting studs protrude through matching holes in dash panel.
On engine side of dash panel, secure heater housing by installing four nuts (10) on mounting studs. Tighten to 5,400 to 7,600 N.mm (47.5 to 67.5 lbf-in).
Connect top section of passenger side floor duct (2, Figure 42) to outlet of heater housing (1). This is a slip-lock type snap joint.
Slip bottom section of passenger side floor duct (3) onto top section and secure to side of heater housing using one screw (4). Attach diffuser (5) if it was removed.

note.para: The driver side duct is connected to the heater housing with a snap mount (slip-lock).

step1.para: Connect driver's side floor duct (7, Figure 41) to heater housing by slipping end of duct over heater housing outlet. Secure floor duct to dash panel under instrument panel using its mounting screw (8). Attach diffuser (9) if it was removed.
Carefully allow IP to return to its normal resting position.
Connect HVAC wiring harness (4) to instrument panel wiring harness.

Install heater core (5) and all related heater components, refer to HEATER CORE, REMOVE AND INSTALL
.

Install evaporator housing (11) onto cowl. Refer to AIR CONDITIONER (EVAPORATOR) HOUSING, REMOVE AND INSTALL
.

Install IP mounting hardware that was removed earlier. More complete procedures for installing the IP can be found in the appropriate CAB section in Group 16 of the Master Service Manual. Typically, the following mounting hardware must be installed:

step2.para: Install two bolts (3, Figure 40) securing each side of IP to dash panel.
Install two bolts (2) securing steering column module to IP.
Install five bolts (1) securing top of IP to dash panel (located near windshield).

step1.para: Install or reconnect any trim panels under the IP that were removed to provide access to IP mounting hardware.
Inside cab, install assist handle and A-pillar trim on passenger's side.
Install A-pillar trim on driver's side.
